DOCNAME: CASE OF KOENDJBIHARIE v. THE NETHERLANDS
CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 5 - Right to liberty and security (Article 5-4 - Order release);Non-pecuniary damage - finding of violation sufficient (Article 41 - Non-pecuniary damage;Just satisfaction)
TEXT: CARDINAL . ORG Mr PERSON is a GPE national , born in GPE . He resides at present in GPE .

CARDINAL . ORG On appeal from a judgment of ORG ( Arrondissementsrechtbank ) of GPE , ORG ( Gerechtshof ) of GPE sentenced him on DATE to a term of CARDINAL months’ imprisonment , to be followed by CARDINAL years’ placement at the ORG ’s disposal ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , for rape aggravated by a previous conviction for the same offence . On CARDINAL DATE ORG ( PERSON ) dismissed his appeal on a point of law .

CARDINAL . ORG On coming out of prison , PERSON was committed on DATE to the ORG psychiatric clinic " Veldzicht " at GPE , from where he absconded on DATE . Suspected of a further rape , he was arrested on DATE and placed in detention on remand , but was acquitted by ORG on DATE . After a period spent at a remand centre in GPE , he was examined at ORG " from DATE to DATE , when he was taken back to the " Veldzicht " clinic .
In the meantime , on DATE , his placement had been extended by ORG until DATE .

CARDINAL . Mr PERSON ’s lawyer , PERSON , learned in DATE that , according to ORG , the applicant ’s period of placement would end on DATE rather than DATE , because it had been suspended during his detention on remand from DATE to CARDINAL DATE ( see paragraphs CARDINAL above and CARDINAL below ) . The applicant objected to this , claiming that his acquittal had deprived the detention of any legal basis and , accordingly , of any effect on the application of LAW ( b ) § QUANTITY of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

On DATE he filed an interlocutory application ( kort geding ) , for his immediate release , with the President of ORG , relying on this argument . He added that his placement had ended on DATE since no application to extend it had been submitted within the statutory time - limit ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .
The President , before whom the ORG had argued in favour of the position taken by ORG , dismissed PERSON application on CARDINAL DATE . The latter appealed .

CARDINAL . ORG In the intervening period , on CARDINAL DATE , the Attorney General at ORG had requested ORG , which had jurisdiction pursuant to LAW b ) of LAW , to extend by DATE the applicant ’s placement at the ORG ’s disposal .

At the hearing on DATE ORG outlined the opinion of the " Veldzicht " clinic , then questioned the member of staff who was responsible for co - ordinating the applicant ’s treatment at the clinic . PERSON put forward the arguments summarised above ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , contending that the Attorney General ’s application was inadmissible . In the alternative she referred to Mr PERSON ’s marriage plans which , she maintained , would reduce the risk of his re - offending . She also asked the court to hear , before giving its decision , CARDINAL of the CARDINAL experts which she had named .
By an interlocutory judgment on DATE the court decided to hear , on DATE , the views of the senior physician of the " Veldzicht " clinic .
CARDINAL . ORG On that date the physician in question failed to appear , but the court did not consider it necessary to call him again , because Mr PERSON no longer intended to marry .
On DATE it extended by DATE the applicant ’s placement , stating that it had been interrupted during his detention on remand .
The applicant , who had absconded on DATE , was informed of this decision by his lawyer , who , after making numerous representations , received a copy of it on DATE .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE before ORG , to which he had appealed against the interlocutory order of CARDINAL DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , the applicant relied on LAW ( h ) of LAW . He considered that his continued confinement was unlawful inasmuch as the judgment of CARDINAL September CARDINAL had not been rendered within DATE of the application for extension submitted by the Attorney General ( see paragraphs CARDINAL above and paragraph CARDINAL below ) . By a judgment of DATE , the court rejected this argument on the ground that the delay in giving judgment did not affect the validity of the decision delivered on DATE by ORG . It also dismissed the complaints directed against the President ’s order , which it upheld .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE Mr PERSON unsuccessfully requested the Minister for ORG to order his conditional release . On DATE he went voluntarily to ORG " , where he was confined .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the Attorney General filed an application for a further extension of the applicant ’s confinement for a period of DATE . During the hearing PERSON repeated her earlier arguments ( see paragraphs CARDINAL and DATE above ) , but the court rejected them by a decision of DATE . However , it refused to allow the Attorney General ’s application , finding that there were not sufficient reasons for granting it .

CARDINAL . ORG Since DATE LAW ( PERSON ) has contained special provisions applying to persons suffering from a mental deficiency or mental illness . The provisions were substantially amended by an LAW of DATE , which came into force on DATE . According to LAW as applicable to the events in the present case ) , the perpetrator of an offence which can not be imputed to him because he suffers from a mental deficiency or mental illness is not liable to punishment . If the protection of public order so requires , the court may direct that such a person be placed at the ORG ’s disposal so that he can receive treatment at the ORG ’s expense .
Such a measure may also be taken in conjunction with a criminal sanction if the convicted person ’s responsibility was merely diminished at the time of the offence ( LAW ( a ) ) .

Under LAW ( b ) LAW , the placement lasts for DATE unless the Government terminates it earlier . This period commences as soon as the judgment ordering it has become final ( paragraph CARDINAL thereof ) ; it is suspended by any other deprivation of liberty resulting from a judicial decision ( paragraph CARDINAL , according to the most widely accepted interpretation ) .

CARDINAL . ORG The court which makes the initial order may extend the confinement , on each occasion for DATE ( Article CARDINAL ( b ) § CARDINAL ) , on an application by the crown prosecutor , himself acting on the opinion of the director of the clinic . To this end , the crown prosecutor has to submit an application to the court in question not DATE and not less than one month before the placement period is due to expire ( Article CARDINAL ( f ) § CARDINAL ) . According to case - law , failure to comply with this requirement renders the application inadmissible .

The prosecutor must attach to his application a copy of the clinic ’s report on the physical and mental health of the person concerned together with a reasoned declaration - preferably by the doctor treating the patient - on the appropriateness of extending the confinement ( LAW ( f ) LAW ) .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL ( g ) governs the procedure to be followed for the examination of the application : if possible the court is to hear the person in question and , if it considers additional information to be necessary , interview witnesses and experts . The crown prosecutor and the lawyer of the person confined may attend any hearing , of which a record is drawn up .
By a circular of DATE , the Minister for ORG issued instructions to the courts to hear the person concerned before extending his placement .

CARDINAL . ORG By virtue of LAW ( h ) LAW , the court is to give its decision within DATE following the lodging of the application . However , LAW b ) § CARDINAL states that the person concerned remains at the Government ’s disposal until the court has ruled on the extension . In a judgment of DATE ( PERSON ( GPE ) DATE , no . CARDINAL ) , ORG ) took the view that the last - mentioned rule applied even if the court exceeded the DATE time - limit , which was merely of an exhortatory nature . While recognising how inconvenient this interpretation might be for the person concerned , the court noted that this did not mean that the latter was entirely without a remedy against such a breach :

" if , once the time - limit laid down in LAW ( h ) has expired , the decision provided for in that provision is arbitrarily delayed , the Government may find itself required , if necessary as a result of legal action by the person confined , to terminate the placement extended pursuant to LAW . "

By a judgment of CARDINAL DATE ( GPE DATE , no . CARDINAL ) ORG ) gave the following clarification regarding the DATE decision : in itself the failure to comply with the time - limit laid down in LAW ( h ) does not give rise to an obligation to terminate the placement ; the existence of such an obligation depends in particular on the extent to which , and the reasons for which , the time - limit is exceeded as well as the personal and social interests at stake .

According to a judgment of ORG ) of DATE ( GPE DATE , no . CARDINAL ) , it falls to the court to decide to what extent it must state its reasons in the order extending the confinement , which is neither delivered in public nor appealable ( LAW ( h ) § CARDINAL ) , but is served on the person concerned ( LAW ( h ) § CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . ORG A person placed at the Government ’s disposal may at any time request the Minister for Justice to revoke the measure . By virtue of LAW ) , the Minister may terminate the confinement at any moment , unconditionally or conditionally , if personal or material circumstances justify such a decision .
